subject: Re: testing dir structure
msgSnippet: Actually we re not distributing the SW, we offer it as a hosted service and hold all software internally.  We do an accounting app that tracks royalty streams,
messageBody:
Actually we're not distributing the SW, we offer it as a hosted
service and hold all software internally. We do an accounting app
that tracks royalty streams, the current market that we're working on
is the music industry where we track royalty income payments to
artists from labels and other income sources and then split the money
within the band. Abit like hearding cats... We're looking forward
to other licensee-licensor markets (books, toys, IP, semiconductor,
clothings, etc) and hoping that they'll be abit more straightfwd.

With that said we are trying to position ourselves to get the SW
middle/back end ready to license as an API, and if that ends up
happening then I'd see value in providing a test suite for the backend
along with the API binaries. We'd see doing this in order to allow
other programmers to view tests, experiment with params, see high and
low values, etc in order to help them come up to speed on our API.
Provides customer confidence that API works as advertised -- as well
as providing us a known good line in the sand, so that if they
mis-impement the API we can point them back to the tests as a means of
establishing a baseline level of API functionality. Helps keep us out
of finger pointing situations with misunderstandings about what
functinality the API provides.

But right now we're (read: me) trying to get a test suite together,
rather get it setup as "right" as I can and avoid refactoring later

Enjoying the book, well written, working well for me. Slow reading but
thats probably more of a pilot error on this end...

Mike
